perturbation.original_text: Joint Content License Relationship. Among other games, Zynga produces and distributes the ZYNGA POKER® game on a number of global platforms, including Apple iOS, Google Android, Facebook and the zynga.com website. The ZYNGA POKER® game features a Zynga Poker Tournaments Mode that Zynga can customize.
perturbation.changed_text: Joint Content License Relationship. Among other games, Zynga produces and distributes the ZYNGA POKER® application on a number of global platforms, including Apple iOS, Google Android, Facebook and the zynga.com website. The ZYNGA POKER® offering features a Zynga Poker Tournaments Mode that Zynga can customize.
perturbation.explanation: The term 'game' is replaced with 'application' and 'offering'. While seemingly synonymous, in the context of digital distribution, these terms can have different legal implications regarding classification and associated regulations. This could lead to confusion about the agreement's scope, as the term 'game' has a more defined meaning under intellectual property law than 'application' or 'offering'.

perturbation.original_text: Royalty. Zynga will pay to WPT ten percent (10%) of the cumulative Net Revenue (as defined in Section 3.b. of the Additional Provisions) (“Royalty”) from the WPT-branded Zynga Poker Tournament Mode or other such use of the WPT brand on the Zynga platform. Zynga shall not be required to pay the Royalty to the extent offset by the Annual Minimum Guarantee payments previously paid to WPT during the Term. Conversely, Zynga shall not be required to make Annual Minimum Guarantee payments to the extent offset by the Royalty previously paid to WPT during the Term.
perturbation.changed_text: Commission. Zynga will pay to WPT ten percent (10%) of the cumulative Net Revenue (as defined in Section 3.b. of the Additional Provisions) (“Payment”) from the WPT-branded Zynga Poker Tournament Mode or other such use of the WPT brand on the Zynga platform. Zynga shall not be required to pay the Payment to the extent offset by the Annual Minimum Guarantee payments previously paid to WPT during the Term. Conversely, Zynga shall not be required to make Annual Minimum Guarantee payments to the extent offset by the Payment previously paid to WPT during the Term.
perturbation.explanation: The word 'Royalty' is changed to 'Commission', and 'Royalty' is renamed to 'Payment'. While in some contexts these might be considered similar, the term 'royalty' often implies ongoing rights to intellectual property, whereas 'commission' typically implies a transactional payment. This change creates confusion about whether the payments are tied to ongoing rights or simply a payment for services, which can affect dispute resolution.

perturbation.original_text: The Royalties to be paid by Zynga to WPT is the percentage of Net Revenue as set forth in Section 5 of the Basic Provisions. “Net Revenue(s)” shall be defined as one hundred percent (100%) of gross revenues and all other receivables of any kind whatsoever received by Zynga or any of Zynga’s affiliates attributable to the use of Paid Currency or in connection with the sale of Virtual Digital Goods derived from use of the WPT-brand on the Zynga platform, less the following actual and verifiable “Allowable Deductions”: (i) out-of-pocket, third-party payment processing and currency system fees, commissions, and platform distribution fees (e.g., Apple, Google or Facebook platform fees); (ii) any governmental taxes (e.g., VAT, excise or sales or use tax, etc.) arising in connection with related receipts, but excluding any taxes on Licensee’s net income; and (iii) charge-backs/refunds/cancellations/fraud.
perturbation.changed_text: The Remuneration to be paid by Zynga to WPT is the percentage of Net Earnings as set forth in Section 5 of the Basic Provisions. “Net Earnings” shall be defined as one hundred percent (100%) of gross receipts and all other profits of any kind whatsoever received by Zynga or any of Zynga’s affiliates attributable to the use of Paid Currency or in connection with the sale of Virtual Digital Goods derived from use of the WPT-brand on the Zynga platform, less the following actual and verifiable “Permissible Expenses”: (i) out-of-pocket, third-party payment processing and currency system fees, commissions, and platform distribution fees (e.g., Apple, Google or Facebook platform fees); (ii) any governmental taxes (e.g., VAT, excise or sales or use tax, etc.) arising in connection with related receipts, but excluding any taxes on Licensee’s net income; and (iii) charge-backs/refunds/cancellations/fraud.
perturbation.explanation: Here, 'Royalties' is changed to 'Remuneration', 'Net Revenue' to 'Net Earnings', 'gross revenues' to 'gross receipts', 'receivables' to 'profits', and 'Allowable Deductions' to 'Permissible Expenses'. While these terms are similar, 'Revenue' and 'Earnings' have distinct accounting meanings. 'Earnings' usually implies that some expenses have already been deducted. 'Deductions' and 'Expenses' are more generalized, the specific accounting implications of each are different. The lack of clarity might cause financial disagreement.
